Graphical abstract A series of VO(IV) complexes with Schiff base ligands derived from vanillin thiophene-2-carboxylic hydrazone (VTCH), vanillin furoic-2-carboxylic hydrazone (VFCH), salicylaldehyde thiophene-2-carboxylic hydrazone (H2STCH) and/or salicylaldehyde furoic-2-carboxylic hydrazone (H2SFCH) have been synthesized as neat and their entrapped complexes into the nanopores of zeolite-Y. These materials were characterized by several techniques: chemical analysis (ICP-OES and elemental) and spectroscopic methods (FT-IR, electronic, XRD, SEMs and BET). All the prepared catalysts were tested over the liquid phase limonene oxidation reaction, using t-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) and/or 30% H2O2 as oxidants. Limonene glycol, carveol and carvone were the main products obtained. It was observed that zeolite-Y based entrapped complexes exhibited higher catalytic activity than neat VO(IV) complexes. These zeolite-Y based entrapped complexes are stable and recyclable under current reaction conditions. Amongst them, [VO(VTCH)2]-Y showed higher catalytic activity (97.7%) with limonene glycol (45.1%), selectivity. Keywords Zeolite-Y VO(IV) complexes Heterogeneous catalysts Limonene oxidation 1 Introduction Recent progresses of vanadium complexes in catalytic and medicinal properties have enthused their design and synthesis [1]. The coordination chemistry of oxovanadium (IV) and oxovanadium (V) is experiencing a frank development with significance in the fields of biological, medicinal, material and synthetic chemistries [2–6]. Especially, the use of vanadium complexes in oxidation catalysis is of particular synthetic interest, namely directed toward organic synthesis. Indeed, this metal displays easily inter convertible different oxidation states, readily accessible high oxidation states, a variety of coordination numbers, a high affinity for oxygen and can behave as a Lewis acid, characteristics that can help its application in redox and Lewis acid catalyzed or promoted reactions [7]. Limonene is the main component of citrus oil being easily obtained from the fruit peel waste. Its derivatives functionalized with oxygen are important intermediates in the synthesis of perfumes, pharmaceuticals, food additives and agrochemicals [8,9]. Epoxides will be the selective products if oxidation occurs at olefinic positions. If the oxidation takes place at allylic positions, the major products will be carveol and carvone, even though a large number of other products may also be formed. In addition, limonene has two olefinic bonds (1, 2 and 8, 9) and the oxidation can take place at either or both of these sites. Allylic oxidation takes place usually via a free radical chain reaction pathway; it generally occurs when the intermediate metallic species are in a low oxidation state [9]. On the other hand, epoxide formation is more likely to occur when oxometallic species are in a high oxidation state, such as O=MnV, O=RuVIII [10]. However, both mechanisms may occur simultaneously, since other variables than the nature of the metallic species (e.g. the stability of the radicals formed), must be taken into account. In acidic reaction media, the limonene oxide may be hydrolyzed forming limonene glycol [11–13]. Generally, limonene is epoxidized via homogenous stoichiometric peracid route [14]. However, this route is not environmentally benign and consequently, it becomes increasingly unacceptable. In addition, Schiff base complexes in particular Metal(Salen) complexes are often described as good epoxidation catalysts, due to their high activity and selectivity [15,16]. However, they might be easily deactivated, in homogeneous liquid solution, due to the formation of μ-oxo dimmers and other polymeric species [17,18]. Catalyst separation from the homogeneous liquid solution is also usually troublesome. Numerous attempts have been made to immobilize homogeneous Schiff base complexes, such as, anchoring these complexes on a polymeric matrix [19], sulfonic acid-functionalized mesoporous SBA-15 [8], encapsulation [20–23], and anchoring of metal bases onto porous inorganic supports [24,25] have also been reported. In particular, zeolites are crystalline aluminosilicates formed by nanocavities and channels of strictly regular dimensions. They are of different sizes and shapes. Especially, the three-dimensional large internal pore (∼13Å) zeolite-Y has been studied here as host lattices. Entrapment of Schiff base complexes into the supercages of zeolite-Y seems to be a good method to satisfy most of the desirable requirements for a suitable support: high surface area and good porosity, chemical inertness, stability, mechanical resistance and to obtain catalysts which preserve the properties of homogeneous systems. Olsen et al. have reported catalytic oxidation of limonene over tetraphenylporphyrin complexes supported in zeolite-Y using H2O2 or tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidants [26]. Prada et al. [27] reported the oxidation of limonene with molecular oxygen using zeolite-Y exchanged with Fe+2, Co+2, Mn+2 and Mo+2. The best results were obtained with NaCoMoY zeolite, with 53% selectivity to 1,2 epoxylimonene (57% conversion). Hutter et al. [28] carried out a comparative study of the epoxidation of various cyclic olefins, including limonene, over different titania-silica catalysts. The authors found that dried titania-silica catalysts showed better catalytic behaviour for these reactions than Ti-zeolites and silica-supported titania. Zeolite-Y based transition metal complexes as heterogeneous catalysts are less extensive. Our laboratory has been exploring the chemistry of this class of catalysts [29–32]. Continuing our study, in this article we report the catalytic oxidation of limonene in the liquid phase over zeolite-Y entrapped VO(IV) complexes as heterogeneous catalysts, using TBHP and/or 30% H2O2 as oxygen source. The catalysts were prepared by flexible ligand (FL) technique. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents All reagents and solvents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received without further purifications. 2.2 Instrumentation Si, Al, Na and V metal ions were determined by ICP-OES (Model: PerkinElmer optima 2000 DV). Carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen were analyzed with a Perkin Elmer, USA 2400-II CHN analyzer. FT-IR spectra of neat and zeolite-Y entrapped VO(IV) complexes were recorded on a Thermo Nicolet IR200 FT-IR spectrometer in KBr. UV-vis spectra were recorded on Spectrophotometer Make/model Varian Cary 500, Shimadzu. The crystallinity of compounds was ensured by XRD using a Bruker AXS D8 Advance X-ray powder diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation as incident beam. The surface area of compounds was measured by multipoint BET method using ASAP 2010, micromeritics surface area analyzer. The scanning electron micrographs of compounds were recorded using a SEM instrument (Model: LEO 1430 VP). The sample materials were coated with a thin film of gold before recording the SEM to protect surface material from thermal damage by the electron beam. All catalyzed reaction products were analyzed using GC–MS having BP-5 capillary column (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm) 95% silicoxane surface and FID detector. The identities of the products were confirmed by GC–MS model Shimadzu, QP-2012. 2.3 Synthesis of Schiff base ligands Schiff base ligands viz. H2STCH and H2SFCH were synthesized by the condensation of salicylaldehyde with thiophene-2-carboxylic acid hydrazide and/or furoic-2-carboxylic acid hydrazide as reported earlier [30]. However, VTCH and VFCH Schiff base ligands were synthesized by the condensation of vanillin with thiophene-2-carboxylic acid hydrazide and/or furoic-2-carboxylic acid hydrazide as discussed earlier [31]. 2.4 Synthesis of VO(IV) based neat complexes The solution of VOSO4·5H2O (2.90g, 10mmol) in 25mL of hot ethanol was added to a 25mL of ethanolic solution of the various Schiff bases [H2STCH (2.47g, 10mmol), H2SFCH (2.31g, 10mmol), VTCH (4.88g, 20mmol) and/or VFCH (5.20g, 20mmol)]. The pH of the solution was adjusted 5-6 by drop wise addition of ethanolic solution of sodium acetate in it. The resulting mixture was heated under reflux on a water bath for 4-5h. After cooling, the solid product was separated by filtration and dried in vacuum. 2.5 Synthesis of VO(IV)-Y (Metal exchanged zeolite-Y) A series of zeolite-Y entrapped VO(IV)-Y complexes have been prepared by flexible ligand (FL) technique as discuss earlier [30]. 2.6 Synthesis of zeolite-Y entrapped VO(IV)complexes Zeolite-Y entrapped VO(IV) complexes were synthesized by taking 1.0g of VO(IV)-Y and successively mixed with an excessive amount of varying Schiff base ligand in ethanol (50mL), following a procedure that reported earlier [30]. 2.7 Catalytic oxidation of limonene In order to establish the performance of neat and zeolite-Y entrapped VO(IV) complexes as catalysts, the oxidation of organic substrate such as limonene was tested. The catalytic oxidation of limonene was undertaken in a two-necked 50mL round bottomed flask. In a typical reaction, 30mmol limonene was taken in 10mL of acetonitrile, then add 0.1g of the catalyst to it and equilibrated at 80°C in an oil-bath for 24h. First, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) was examined as oxidant in acetonitrile and then TBHP in acetonitrile was tested. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Characterization of zeolite-Y entrapped VO(IV)complexes The chemical analysis data of neat and their entrapped VO(IV) complexes are given in Table 1 . The C, H, N analysis results of the neat VO(IV) complexes showed close similarity to the theoretical values. The chemical analyses of the entrapped compounds reveal the presence of organic matter with a C/N ratio almost similar to that for neat complexes. Furthermore, the Si and Al contents in VO(IV)-Y and their entrapped complexes are almost in the same ratio as in the parent zeolite. This indicates little changes in the zeolite framework due to the absence of dealumination in metal ion exchange. Table 2 lists the specific surface area and specific micropore volume measurement data of Na-Y, VO(IV)-Y and their entrapped complexes. The lowering of the pore volume and surface area supported the fact that VO(IV) complexes are present within the zeolite cages and not on the external surface. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of Na-Y, VO(IV)-Y and their entrapped complexes were recorded at 2θ values between 2° and 70°. The XRD patterns of zeolite-Y entrapped VO(IV) complexes are similar to those of neat zeolite-Y and VO(IV)-Y (Fig. 1 .). This indicates that the zeolite crystallinity is preserved on entrapping complexes. Nevertheless, slight modification occurs, as confirmed by the alteration of the relative intensity of the peaks at 2 2 0 and 3 1 1 reflections (2θ of about 9° and 12°, respectively). For neat zeolite-Y, I 2 2 0 is higher than I 3 1 1, upon exchanging the metal ion or after the entrapment process, I 2 2 0 becomes lower than I 3 1 1. This is typical for the formation of large transition metal complex ion in the supercages of zeolite-Y, indicating that at least part of vanadium ions in the hydrothermally synthesized VO(IV)-Y samples formed complexes with Schiff bases in the supercages of zeolite-Y [33]. Scanning electron micrographs of [VO(VTCH)2]-Y recorded before and after Soxhlet extraction as shown in Fig. 2 . The SEM taken before purification shows the presence of some extraneous particles on the external surface. After Soxhlet extraction, no surface complexes are seen and the particle boundaries on the exterior of zeolite are clearly distinguishable. The presence of analogous surface morphology before and after encapsulation into zeolite-Y confirms that entrapment has not affected the surface crystallinity [34]. The FTIR spectral data of Schiff base ligands, their neat and entrapped complexes are discussed and tabulated in Table 3 . The intensity of the peaks in entrapped complexes is, though, weak due to their low concentration in zeolite matrix (Fig. 3 ). A sharp band is seen in all entrapped complexes at ∼1070cm−1, which is not observed in the corresponding ligands as well as in their neat complexes (Fig. 4 ). Hence, it can be assigned to the zeolite framework vibration. Other major zeolite framework bands appear around 1190, 830 and 640cm−1 [35]. Comparison of the spectra of neat complexes with Schiff base ligands provides evidence for the coordinating mode of ligand in the complexes. The Schiff base ligands viz. H2STCH, H2SFCH, VTCH and/or VFCH exhibit a sharp band at ∼1638cm−1 due to ν (C=N) (azomethine). On complexation formation this band shifted towards lower wave number and appears at 1605–1628cm−1, indicating that the coordination takes place through azomethine nitrogen. In addition, two sharp bands are observed at ∼3185 and ∼1690cm−1, which may be assigned to the ν (N–H) and ν (C=O) bands of the lateral chain of the Schiff base ligands. On complexation, these bands were absent in the spectra of neat complexes. On the contrary, the new absorption band attributed to ν (C–O) is observed at ca. 1300cm−1. The phenolic–OH vibration of the Schiff base ligands viz. STCH and/or SFCH (∼3380cm−1) disappeared in that of the neat complexes, indicating the involvement of this group in coordination with the metal ion, via de-protonation. Neat VO(IV) complexes exhibit a sharp band at ∼920cm−1 due to ν (V=O) stretch, while the location of such ν (V=O) band in zeolite entrapped VO(IV) complexes was not possible may be due to the appearance of a strong and broad band in this region due to zeolite frame work. A broad band in the region 3440–3460cm−1, and a weaker band in the region 620–600cm−1 in all neat complexes derived from STCH and/or SFCH Schiff base ligands are attributed to–OH stretching and wagging vibrations, respectively, indicated the presence of coordinated water molecules [36]. The electronic spectral data of Schiff base ligands, neat and their entrapped VO(IV) complexes are presented in Table 4 . The electronic spectral profiles of neat and entrapped complexes are represented in Fig. 5 . The electronic spectra of Schiff base ligands viz. H2STCH and/or H2SFCH exhibit three bands at ∼210, ∼340 and ∼380nm and these are assigned due to ILCT, π→π* and n→π* transitions, respectively. In the spectra of [VO(STCH)·H2O] and [VO(SFCH)·H2O], the characteristic bands appear at ∼230 and ∼335nm while the third band appeared at 408nm in the spectra of [VO(STCH)·H2O]. A band appearing at ∼240nm is assigned to ligand to metal charge transfer band. Both the entrapped VO(IV) complexes derived from STCH and/or SFCH ligands, exhibit essentially similar spectral patterns (Fig. 5) as compared with their neat complexes. Presence of these bands confirms the existence of complexes in the cavity of zeolite-Y. However, the electronic spectra of Schiff bases viz. VTCH and/or VFCH exhibit one intense band at ∼330nm due to intra ligand charge transfer transition; this band undergo hypsochromic shift (∼320nm) in the spectra of their neat complexes, [VO(VFCH)2] and [VO(VTCH)2] resulting chelation of ligand with the transition metal ion. [VO(STCH)·H2O]-Y and [VO(SFCH)·H2O]-Y also exhibit characteristic band at ∼220nm, while in [VO(STCH)·H2O]-Y the band appearing at 255nm is assignable to ligand to metal charge transfer band. All these bands shift to higher wave length side indicating the restructuring of the ligand after coordination to the metal ion. On the basis of all these studies, the structures as shown in Scheme 1 have been proposed for these complexes. 3.2 Catalytic Activity The catalytic oxidation of limonene over neat complexes and zeolite-Y entrapped VO(IV) complexes was undertaken in a two-necked 50mL round bottomed flask. In a typical reaction, 30% H2O2 and/or TBHP as oxidants gives major products viz. carvone, carveol and limonene glycol. Reaction conditions for the liquid-phase oxidation of limonene were optimized as follows: limonene (30mmol), 75mmol of TBHP, catalyst (0.1g), acetonitrile (10mL) at 80°C for 24h. Only negligible conversion occurs in the presence of neat zeolite-Y material, suggesting that the vanadium metal complexes are responsible for the oxidation of limonene, as shown in Table 5 . Furthermore, the effect of different oxidants such as TBHP and/or 30% H2O2 on limonene oxidation was carried out by keeping all other parameters constant as shown in Table 6 . The percentage conversion of limonene to carvone, carveol and limonene glycol are shown in Fig. 6 . It is clear from the results that the selectivity of limonene glycol formation found to be varied (29-45%) from catalyst to catalyst. The conversion (%) of limonene by zeolite-Y entrapped complexes increases in the order: [VO(VFCH)2]-Y<[VO(SFCH)·H2O]-Y<[VO(STCH)·H2O]-Y<[VO(VTCH)2]-Y. Neat complexes have also shown good activity but the conversion of limonene is lower as expected (Table 5). Interestingly, it was observed that entrapped complexes are more effective than the neat complexes. The heterogeneous catalysts were both active and selective for the formation of limonene glycol. The physically encapsulated catalysts had higher conversions of limonene (94.60–97.70%) and limonene glycol selectivity (39.10–45.10%) than the homogeneous analog (Table 5). As observed in other systems [37,38], the higher conversion and selectivity may be explained by assuming that under homogeneous conditions, the reaction rate is suppressed by the poor solubility of the complex in the solvent, by self-degradation. Furthermore, the selectivity for limonene glycol, the supported species may play an important role. Since aluminium rich faujasites have a hydrophilic nature, it is anticipated that polar products like limonene glycol, carveol and carvone will be preferentially adsorbed by the catalyst compared with apolar inorganic polymers, therefore, the relative bigger amount of limonene glycol is formed among the products. On the other hand, it was observed that entrapped catalyst [VO(VTCH)2]-Y is much better than [VO(VFCH)2]-Y or [VO(STCH).H2O]-Y or [VO(STCH).H2O]-Y. The entrapped catalyst [VO(VTCH)2]-Y gives higher conversion (%) of limonene, consequently this catalyst is taken as representative catalyst for evaluation of optimal reaction condition like effect of amount of catalyst, effect of temperature, effect of reaction time, effect of ratio of substrate and oxidant and effect of various solvent on the oxidation of limonene along with their possible explanations are summarized below: The amount of catalyst has a significant effect on the oxidation of limonene. Five different amounts of [VO(VTCH)2]-Y catalyst viz., 0.03, 0.05, 0.07, 0.10 and 0.15g were used by keeping all the reaction parameters fixed. The results are shown in Fig. 7 , representing 20.06, 39.56, 71.25, 97.7 and 95.0% conversion corresponding to 0.03, 0.05, 0.07, 0.10 and 0.15g catalyst, respectively. The greater conversion percentage was observed with 0.10g catalyst but there was no significant loss is observed in the conversion percentage of reaction when 0.15g of catalyst was employed. Therefore, 0.10g amount of catalyst was taken to be optimal. To determine the effect of mole ratio of limonene and TBHP on oxidation of limonene, five different mole ratio (1:1, 1:1.5, 1:2, 1:2.5, 1:3) were taken by keeping all other reaction parameters (10ml acetonitrile, 0.1g entrapped complex, 80°C, 24 hr for 30mmol limonene) fixed. As shown in Fig. 8 , conversion (%) of limonene increases from 80.19 to 97.7% with increase in the mole ratio of limonene and TBHP from 1:1 to 1:2.5, further increase in the mole ratio to 1:3, leads to decrease in the limonene conversion to 90.12%. Therefore, mole ratio 1:2.5 of limonene and TBHP was taken to be as optimum. The effect of various solvents over the oxidation of limonene with [VO(VTCH)2]-Y was studied keeping other reaction parameters fixed. Four different solvents viz. chloroform, methanol, acetone, and acetonitrile gave 85.6, 92.1, 90.9, and 97.7% conversion respectively. As demonstrated in Fig. 9 , the behavior of limonene oxidation in various solvents is strikingly different. Acetonitrile gives the best conversion results, followed by methanol. From this observation, the reduction in (%) conversion of limonene in methanol, chloroform and acetone may be explained by the low solubility of TBHP in a solvent by which the reaction could not proceed fast. Acetonitrile is a polar solvent with a very high dielectric constant, it may readily dissolve TBHP along with the limonene and consequently can direct the reactants in such a way that properly be adsorbed on the catalyst surface and increasing the efficiency of the conversion. Highly polar solvents like acetonitrile may facilitate formation of active oxygen species and thereby enhance the catalytic activity [39]. The best conversion for limonene in the acetonitrile as a solvent is shown in Fig. 9. The oxidation of limonene was examined over the temperature range of 50 to 85°C, as presented in Fig. 10 . The limonene conversion (%) was increased from 71.60 to 97.70% for reaction time 24h, when the temperature was increased from 50 to 80°C. Limonene conversion decreases, when the reaction temperature was further increased to 85°C as shown in Table 7 . This may be due to quick decomposition of TBHP. This result suggests that the optimum reaction temperature for oxidation of limonene was 80°C. Catalytic oxidation of limonene using varying homogeneous and/or heterogeneous systems has been studied previously by some other groups as discussed here. The Mn-salen complex when used with Y zeolite was presented to give 42% selectivity at 95% conversion [40]. Similarly, epoxidation of (R)-(+)-limonene with H2O2 as oxygen donor in the presence of NaY-FeTMePP catalyst leads to 81% of limonene conversion with 64% selectivity of 8,9-epoxy-p-menth-1-ene [41]. Other supported complexes, such as methyltrioxorhenium encapsulated in polystyrene with tridentate ligands (trans-1,2-cyclohexanediamine-MTO), quantitatively converted limonene into the epoxide with a yield >98%, at 263K with H2O2 as oxidant [42]. The oxidation of (R)-(+)-limonene with PVP-25/MTO in ionic liquid viz. [BMIM][BF4] at room temperature gave ˃98% conversion with bis-epoxylimonene as the main reaction product with selectivity of 92% [43]. Bermejo et al. reported [44] oxidation of (R)-(+)-limonene with H2O2 in the presence of Fe(bpmen)(OTf)2 led to 100% conversion with mixtures of products viz. monoepoxides and diepoxides. By using 1 equiv. of the oxidant and 5% of the catalyst, the terminal trisubstituted monoepoxide was the major isolated product with 70% selectivity. However, increasing the amount of oxidant (3 equiv.) and catalyst (15%) led to the isolation of the diepoxide with 90% selectivity was observed. Silica supported manganese complex, Mn2Lc.SiO2 was presented to give 46.1% selectivity of limonene cis-1,2-epoxide at 97.3% conversion (TOF: 40.5h−1) [45]. Methyltrioxorhenium(VII) (CH3ReO3, MTO)-catalyzed epoxidation of limonene with use of 3-methylpyrazole as the additives successfully afforded limonene epoxides in excellent yields [46]. The use of excess H2O2 (25mmol) and prolonged reaction time (8 hr) resulted in 100% limonene conversion with the selective formation of limonene diepoxide (98% selectivity). Using TBHP as oxidant, a 53% yield of 1,2-limonene epoxide at 100% conversion was obtained, in line with the results obtained with Mn-salen complex supported on Y zeolite, described above [40]. High yields of limonene epoxides viz. limonene 1,2-epoxide (55%), 8,9-epoxide (30%), bis-epoxide (10%) were obtained in the oxidation of limonene (72% conversion) using 2-Fe-H2O2 system [47]. Louloudi et al. [48] have developed trisimidazole/Mn(II) system (MnCl2/L3imid) as homogeneous catalyst for limonene epoxidation with H2O2. It was found to be ammonium acetate-dependent and gave remarkable effectiveness and selectivity. The major products detected from oxidation of limonene, were two epoxides (Z- and E-isomers) derived from epoxidation of the 1,2-double bond and two diastereoisomers derived from the exocyclic 8,9-double bond. The total yield of oxidation products was raised at 90% with 900 TONs and 300 TOF for MnCl2/L3imid. Tetra-n-butylammonium salt of [γ-1,2-H2SiV2W10O40]4–(TBA-1), which has a {VO-(μ-OH)2-VO} core, could catalyzed the epoxidation of limonene in the presence of only one equivalent of H2O2 with a high yield of limonene 8,9-epoxide (89%) at 91% conversion [49]. V2O5/TiO2 catalysts prepared by different sol–gel procedures were tested as heterogeneous catalysts over limonene oxidation using concentrated and diluted TBHP as oxidant, yields polymers as main products. [9]. Limonene oxide, limonene glycol, carveol and carvone are also formed in small amounts. Our own results show that, when [VO(VTCH)2]-Y were used for oxidation of limonene with TBHP as oxidant under optimized reaction condition gave 97.7% limonene conversion in 24hours with selective formation of 45.1% limonene glycol. The reusability of [VO(VTCH)2]-Y catalyst was tested over three consecutive runs and the results are illustrated in Table 8 . The used catalyst was recovered and rinsed with copious amount of distilled water and acetone after each catalytic run. The washed catalyst was dried at 120°C for 24h before reuse. The catalytic activity after the first cycle of [VO(VTCH)2]-Y has an obvious decrease compared with the fresh catalyst (Table 8). This decrease of activity is also accompanied with an apparent decrease in the amount of vanadium content. It may be due to small amounts of vanadium and excess ligands were trapped in zeolite in the catalyst [VO(VTCH)2]-Y owing to diffusion being hindered by vanadium complexes in the cages. On the basis of this fact, we assume that such small amounts of vanadium and ligand, which participated in the catalytic cycle of encapsulated complexes, was transferred from zeolite into solution during the reaction. This guess was confirmed by the AAS result of the vanadium content in the reacted mixture. After the second cycle, the vanadium content of the immobilized catalyst remained almost unchanged and no significant catalytic activity loss was observed. This fact demonstrates that the complex entrapped in the supercages of zeolite Y affords reactive centers, and the porous support prevents the complex from decomposition and dimerization under reaction conditions, and makes it recoverable. This result suggested that the catalyst was sufficiently stable and reusable with minimal loss of reactivity. 3.2.1 Catalytic reaction mechanism The merely tentative mechanism for the oxidation of limonene by zeolite-Y entrapped VO(IV) complexes is shown in Scheme 2 . The catalyzed oxidation of limonene could hypothetically occur via two possible pathways as shown in Scheme 2, one is a double bond attack where the catalyst interacts with TBHP as oxidant to form an active metal-oxo species (I). This activated radical species •OOV5+L2/NaY, which results into oxidative addition to the C–C double bond of limonene molecule to give an intermediate (II). The intermediate (II) undergoes migratory insertion to give cyclic epoxide formation (IV) through intermediate (III) and regenerates OV+4L2/NaY. Epoxide species (IV) can further react with H+/H2O to give limonene glycol (V). However in the second pathway species (I) attacks the allylic position of the limonene resulting the formation of species (VI) which results in the formation of carveol product through intermediate (VII). The attack of species (I) •OOV5+L2/NaY, further on the carveol through (VIII) which under goes epoxidation to form a carvone product with removal of water [50] and regenerates the catalyst. 4 Conclusions In summary, the zeolite entrapped oxovanadium (IV) complexes and their respective neat metal complexes have been prepared and characterized. Catalytic activity of these complexes has been tested for the oxidation of limonene using H2O2 and/or TBHP as oxidant. TBHP has been found to be a more efficient oxidant than H2O2 for oxidation of limonene. Limonene catalyzed by neat and entrapped complexes gives mainly three reaction products carveol, carvone, and limonene glycol with higher selectivity towards limonene glycol. The entrapped complexes exhibit enhanced selectivity in the oxidation reaction. The size of the macrocyclic ring and substitution also influence the catalytic activity. These entrapped systems offer structural integrity by having a uniform distribution of the metal complex in the pore structure of the support. The zeolite framework keeps the guest complexes discrete and prevents their dimerization leading to retention of the catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: A series of VO(IV) complexes with Schiff base ligands derived from vanillin thiophene-2-carboxylic hydrazone (VTCH), vanillin furoic-2-carboxylic hydrazone (VFCH), salicylaldehyde thiophene-2-carboxylic hydrazone (H2STCH) and/or salicylaldehyde furoic-2-carboxylic hydrazone (H2SFCH) have been synthesized as neat and their entrapped complexes into the nanopores of zeolite-Y. These materials were characterized by several techniques: chemical analysis (ICP-OES and elemental) and spectroscopic methods (FT-IR, electronic, XRD, SEMs and BET). All the prepared catalysts were tested over the liquid phase limonene oxidation reaction, using t-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) and/or 30% H2O2 as oxidants. Limonene glycol, carveol and carvone were the main products obtained. It was observed that zeolite-Y based entrapped complexes exhibited higher catalytic activity than neat VO(IV) complexes. These zeolite-Y based entrapped complexes are stable and recyclable under current reaction conditions. Amongst them, [VO(VTCH)2]-Y showed higher catalytic activity (97.7%) with limonene glycol (45.1%), selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic oxidation of limonene over zeolite-Y entrapped oxovanadium (IV) complexes as heterogeneous catalysts
